title: Emil Bildilli
text:
Emil "Hill Billy" Bildilli (September 16, 1912 – September 16, 1946) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who appeared in 41 <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> over all or part of five seasons for the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Browns">St. Louis Browns</a> (–). A left-hander born in <a href="Diamond%2C%20Indiana">Diamond, Indiana</a>, he was listed as tall and .
Playing career.
Minor leagues.
Bildilli grew up in <a href="Shepardsville%2C%20Indiana">Shepardsville</a> in <a href="Vigo%20County%2C%20Indiana">Vigo County, Indiana</a>, and attended <a href="Clinton%20High%20School%20%28Indiana%29">Clinton High School</a>. As a young man, he moved to <a href="Terre%20Haute%2C%20Indiana">Terre Haute</a>, where he played <a href="semiprofessional">semiprofessional</a> baseball. In 1937, Terre Haute's Class B <a href="Illinois-Indiana-Iowa%20League">Illinois-Indiana-Iowa League</a> team, the <a href="Terre%20Haute%20Tots">Tots</a>, a Browns' <a href="farm%20system">farm club</a>, signed Bildilli, then 24, to his first pro contract. He appeared in 15 games and posted a 7–7 <a href="win-loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">won–lost record</a> before the Tots folded on July 3. Bildilli then spent the rest of the 1937 minor-league campaign with the Class C <a href="Johnstown%20Johnnies">Johnstown Johnnies</a> of the <a href="Middle%20Atlantic%20League">Middle Atlantic League</a>.
Major leagues.
In late August, he was recalled all the way to St. Louis, getting into four games for the 1937 Browns (with one <a href="starting%20pitcher">start</a>), but he struggled, losing his only <a href="decision%20%28baseball%29">decision</a> with a 10.13 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a>.
Bildilli was back in the minor leagues for the bulk of 1938, but it was a banner year for him. He won 18 of 22 decisions for <a href="Springfield%20Browns">Springfield</a> of the Illinois-Indiana-Iowa League, and was effective in three appearances in the high-level <a href="Texas%20League">Texas League</a> with <a href="San%20Antonio%20Missions">San Antonio</a>. He earned another late-season trial with the Browns, working in five games and recording his first <a href="MLB">MLB</a> victory, but he remained ineffective, with 7.06 ERA. St. Louis sent him back to San Antonio in , where he helped pitch the Missions into the playoffs by winning 22 games, tied for tops in the Texas League. Back with the Browns for a third consecutive September stint, he posted two <a href="complete%20game">complete game</a>s in as many starts and lowered his ERA to 3.32 in 19 <a href="innings%20pitched">innings pitched</a>, setting the stage for his season, Bildilli's only full year in the major leagues.
Appearing in 28 games for a sixth-place <a href="1940%20St.%20Louis%20Browns%20season">1940 Browns team</a> that lost 87 games, Bildilli compiled a modest 2–4 won–lost mark, and his earned run average was a poor 5.57. However, on April 30, 1940, at <a href="Yankee%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Yankee Stadium</a> and facing the defending world champion <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, Bildilli turned in a scintillating performance. After allowing <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> to the first two batters he faced—a <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triple</a> to <a href="Frankie%20Crosetti">Frankie Crosetti</a> and an <a href="runs%20batted%20in">RBI</a> <a href="single%20%28baseball%29">single</a> to <a href="Red%20Rolfe">Red Rolfe</a>—Bildilli settled down and allowed only two more baserunners, both of whom he <a href="base%20on%20balls">walked</a>. The Browns battled back to score two <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a> in the middle innings, rewarding Bildilli with a two-hit, complete game 2–1 triumph.
He pitched only one more season in professional baseball. In 1941, after two early-season games and only 2 innings pitched, St. Louis sent him to <a href="Toledo%20Mud%20Hens">Toledo</a>, their top affiliate, where he struggled to a 5–9 (5.57) record. He closed the book on a major league career that included a 4–8 record and 5.84 earned run average in 41 games, including 17 starts. He registered seven career complete games and one <a href="save%20%28baseball%29">save</a>. In 148 innings pitched, he surrendered 184 hits and 75 walks, with 55 <a href="strikeout">strikeout</a>s.
After pro baseball.
In 1942, Bildilli took a job with the fire department in <a href="Muncie%2C%20Indiana">Muncie, Indiana</a>, and played <a href="semi-professional">semi-professional</a>ly. After defeating a barnstorming team from the <a href="Negro%20leagues">Negro leagues</a> in <a href="Fort%20Wayne%2C%20Indiana">Fort Wayne</a> on September 14, 1946, he was driving home to Muncie when his car ran off the road and hit a tree. Bildilli suffered a fractured skull, and died two days later in <a href="Hartford%20City%2C%20Indiana">Hartford City</a> on his 34th birthday, leaving his wife and two children.
